From underneath, you can see an enormous humanoid figure in a dark hooded cloak bending over on the other side of the rift. The figure speaks a few words in a booming voice that can be heard by any creature within 1 mile of the rift, before placing a hand over it and releasing a massive {@dice d20} dice through the rift, collapsing downwards to the point you chose. The enormous dice resembles the dice you used in the casting of the spell.

Any creature in the 60-foot radius, 500-foot high cylinder underneath the rift must make a Strength, Dexterity, Constitution, Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma saving throw, counting the amount of successes and failures in total. The enormous magical dice affects both the physical and mental, and acts as the true test of a creature's full capabilities. A creature that failed 5 or more saving throws gets brutally crushed by the dice, taking {@damage 15d20} force damage. A creature that failed 3 or 4 saving throws takes half as much damage, and a creature that failed 2 or less saving throws takes no damage.

As the dice lands, it starts to disappear in a cloud of smoke from the bottom up, but remains motionless for enough time to identify the result of the roll. The DM then rolls a {@dice d20}, symbolizing the result of the massive dice. The effect produced by each number is listed below.

1-The power of being able to cast this spell pushes your mental and physical body beyond its limits past the threshold of life and death. You instantly die, turning into magical dust that flows with the wind in the direction of the rift. You cannot be brought back to life by any spell except for true resurrection if you die in this way.

2-A deafening boom followed by a wave of intense heat bursts out from the dice as it lands. Every creature within 500 feet of the dice must succeed on a Constitution saving throw or become {@condition deafened} for 1 hour. Additionally, the area within 1 mile of the dice becomes placed under the same effect as an antimagic field for 24 hours.
3-You and every creature within 150 feet of the point you chose is each instantly transported to a random location in the Astral Plane.

4-An adult red dragon appears at the point you chose, hostile to any creature that it sees nearby. It adds itself to the turn order and will begin destroying everything on sight, with breath initially recharged. The dragon will disappear after {@dice 1d6} hours.

5-A cool ripple flows throughout your body, returning your mind and body to a fundamental and balanced state. All your ability scores instantly become 10 and you end any spell you are concentrating on. You deattune to any magic items you were attuned to previously, cannot use any class abilities, lose all your racial traits, and cannot cast any spells above 3rd level. Additionally, you lose all your proficiencies and your alignment becomes true neutral. This effect lasts for the next {@dice 1d6} days and can only be reverted by a wish spell.

6-You are instantly engulfed by magical flames that expand outwards to affect all creatures within 30 feet of you. Every creature within the area of effect must make a Dexterity saving throw, taking {@damage 12d12} fire damage on a failed save, and half as much on a successful one. If this damage reduces your hit point to 0, you instantly die and your body is transported to the Nine Hells where you are revived as a lemure.

7-Dark magic drains your arcane energy. You lose all your spell slots until your next long rest and your Strength Score is reduced to 3 for the next {@dice 1d6} days. Taking a long rest will decrease the recovery time by 2 days.

8-You release an uncontrolled burst of necromantic magic. {@dice 1d3} thin green beams of energy shoot out from you in the direction of the closest creatures regardless of it being friendly or hostile. Each target is subject under the disintegrate spell against your spell save DC.

9-Five chasmes fly out from the circular rift right as it begins to close. They add themselves to the turn order under one roll and will behave like normally. The chasmes will disappear after {@dice 1d6} hours.
10-You and every creature within 150 feet of the point you chose changes to the closest Neutral alignment on the Lawful-Chaotic scale.
11-You and every creature within 150 feet of the point you chose changes to the closest Neutral alignment on the Good-Evil scale.
12-You gain insight of what is to come in the coming future. You instantly cast divination 3 times without consuming any material components and with a 100 percent success rate each time.

13-You grow larger by one size, and your muscles are imbued with a magical strength that guides your newfound feral senses and savagery. You score critical hits on a natural 15-20 with melee weapon attacks, and you can roll one of the weapon's damage dice one additional time and add it to the extra damage on a critical hit with this weapon. You cannot be surprised by unseen attackers and you are aware of the location of any creature within 30 feet of you given you are not {@condition blinded} or {@condition deafened}. Additionally, your Strength score increases by 4 to a maximum of 24. These benefits last for the next {@dice 1d6} days.

14-Silvery wings spread out behind your arms, and a slight wind curls underneath you to form a twister around your legs. Your movement does not provoke opportunity attacks and you gain a flying hover speed equal to your movement speed. When you are subjected to an Effect that allows you to make a Dexterity saving throw to take only half damage, you instead take no damage if you succeed on the saving throw, and only half damage if you fail. Additionally, your Dexterity score increases by 4 to a maximum of 24. These benefits last for the next {@dice 1d6} days.

15-Your body revitalizes, clearing you of any curses, negative conditions, and disease. The surge of health retains within your body and allows you to take more damage than you normally are able to. You become immune to poison damage, and gain resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage from non-magical attacks. Additionally, your Constitution score increases by 4 to a maximum of 24. These benefits last for the next {@dice 1d6} days. This change in Constitution also increases your hit point maximum until the spell ends.

16-Your head glows with a brilliant pink light as normally inaccessible knowledge flows into your mind. You instantly learn every spell from any class spell list. Additionally, your Intelligence score increases by 4 to a maximum of 24. These benefits last for the next {@dice 1d6} days.

17-Your eyes are replaced with a white emptiness that emits bright light out to 10 feet, giving you a divine awareness of everything that is happening around you. You gain {@sense truesight} out to 120 feet, the ability to see through walls, and are not affected by any divination or enchantment spells. Additionally, your Wisdom score increases by 4 to a maximum of 24. These benefits last for the next {@dice 1d6} days.

18-You gain an uncanny ability to persuade and deceive exceptionally, and your words appear more eloquent and confident to everyone around you. Whenever you make a Charisma related check, you can replace the number you roll with a 10. Creatures get disadvantage on Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) checks made against you. Additionally, your Charisma score increases by 4 to a maximum of 24. These benefits last for the next {@dice 1d6} days.

19-A magical insurgence flows through your body, replenishing your stamina and arcanic abilities. You regain all expended spell slots, including the 9th level spell slot used to cast this spell. You regain all your hit points and recover any used abilities. Additionally, the dice component you used for this spell is not consumed.

20-You gain the power to cheat luck and enter a divine state where you perform far beyond the abilities of a mortal. For the next 24 hours, all your non{@dice  - d20} rolls give the maximum possible value and your greatest ability score is replaced by a 30.

spell.name: Microseism
entries: You blast the ground with seismic energy, sending a 4-foot tall rolling wave of earth outwards from you in all directions. All creatures within the area of effect must make a Dexterity saving throw to jump over the moving earth. On a failed save, the creature is caught by the wave, taking {@damage 5d8} bludgeoning damage and is pushed 15 feet away from you. On a successful save, the creature is able to jump over the rolling earth, escaping the pushback and taking half as much damage.
A Tiny creature automatically fails the saving throw. A Large creature has advantage on the saving throw, and a Huge or larger creature automatically succeeds.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: Als je deze spreuk uitspreekt met een spreukengroef van niveau 4 of hoger, neemt de schade toe met {@dice 1d8} voor elk niveau hoger dan 3.

spell.name: Midnight Melody

components.m: a flute and a miniature sculpture of the moon

entries: You create a massive illusion filled with the tranquility of a moonlit midnight in a forest meadow. A 60-foot radius black spherical dome appears at a point within range. Every creature that starts its turn inside of the dome must make a Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition charmed} by the spell. A creature that is immune to being {@condition charmed} is not affected by the illusion.

The black dome is not a physical object and can be passed through normally. Creatures outside of the dome and uncharmed creatures inside the dome see a dark but translucent covering instead of a pure black wall. Charmed creatures inside the dome take the black dome to be the night sky, stars shimmering brightly in every direction. A huge gibbard moon shines with brilliant white light above an elven forest that resembles the Feywild inside of this illusion. Woodwind music whistles throughout the illusory night, and small ponds of still water reside next to riverbanks lined with rows of blossoming crystal flowers, seemingly dancing in the light breeze.

A creature {@condition charmed} by the illusion enters a peaceful state of mind, sees and hears no other creatures, loses concentration, and is hypnotized by the gleaming light of the large moon. It hears and sees nothing from outside the sphere, and cannot receive information via divination spells or telepathically. It loses its bonus action and reaction and must use its movement every turn to move as close as it can to the point directly underneath the moon at the center of the sphere, and must use its action to {@action Dash} if not there yet. Otherwise, it loses its action on that turn. A creature that ends its turn inside of the illusion gains 10 temporary hit points, as beautiful naturistic music plays through its head. A creature can have a maximum of 80 temporary hit points granted by the music of the spell. A {@condition charmed} creature can make a Wisdom saving throw at the end of each of its turns. On a success, it is no longer {@condition charmed}, and can attempt to run out of the illusion. The area affected by the spell is considered difficult terrain.

If a {@condition charmed} creature takes damage from a source outside of the sphere, it is no longer {@condition charmed}. When the spell ends or when a creature leaves the area of effect, it loses all its temporary hit points given by the spell, if any. The creature then must make a Wisdom saving throw, taking psychic damage equal to 40 + the amount of cumulative temporary hit points granted by this spell on a failed save, or half as much on a successful one. This damage can not exceed 120.

spell.name: Mordenkainen's Marionette Mask

components.m: a white porcelain mask

entries: A puppeteer's mask appears on your face and remains there for the duration. The mask is a mixture of swirling black and white energy, with empty black voids as the eyes. The mouth is a pair of dark red lips, and it moves as you talk. The first creature that is not {@condition blinded} that looks at you has to make a Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition charmed}, as the hypnotic patterns of the mask compels it to fall into a trance. On any of your subsequent turns, you can use a bonus action to force the creature to spend its turn to do the same action as you to the best of its abilities. For example, if you cast fireball and it doesn't know how to cast that spell, it can possibly cast fire bolt. This assumption cannot allow the creature to cast anything at a higher level than you. The attack will be directed towards the same target if it is a ranged attack. If it casts a spell above 3rd level as a result of copying your action, it can make a Wisdom saving throw with a DC equal to 10 + the spell's level. On a success, it does not cast the spell and the spell ends. If you do not usher the creature to follow your action for a round, it stands motionless, {@condition paralyzed}, as it stares off into your mask with its voidish black eyes.

If at any time you leave the creature's line of sight, the spell ends. The creature can make another Wisdom saving throw at the end of each of its turns or if your action forces it to hurt one of its allies, ending the spell on a success. If it takes any damage, the spell immediately ends.

spell.name: Noxious Fumes

components.m: oleander and a handful of sulfur powder

entries: You slowly release a cloud of toxic fumes from your hands with a loud hissing sound. Each creature in a 60-foot cone must make a Constitution saving throw. A creature takes {@damage 5d10} poison damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. The thick fumes linger in the air, making the area of effect lightly obscured until the beginning of your next turn.

On a failed save, a creature not immune to poison damage is inflicted with the {@condition poisoned} condition for 1 minute, heaving and gagging as the fumes penetrate the body. This magical poison can end on a creature that receives a healing spell of 6th level or higher.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 7th level or higher, the poison damage increases by {@dice 1d10} for every level above 6th.

spell.name: Oblivion

components.m: a handful of crystal shards

entries: You attempt to exhaust the control and awareness of a creature you can see in range, leaving it as a moving body of aloof, naive impulsivity. The creature must make a Wisdom saving throw.

On a failed save, the creature's Wisdom score becomes 1. The creature is completely clueless to its own surroundings, and so any attack against it is made with advantage. It can only use the {@action Attack} and Cast a Spell action options in combat, and is unable to take any reactions. The creature becomes driven solely by its natural desires and has no understanding of its surroundings.
These effects last for 24 hours, and can also be ended by greater restoration, heal, or wish.

spell.name: Omniscience

m.text: a golden eye and crystal ball worth at least 500 gp which is consumed

entries: You strain your mind past its normal limits for a brief moment, taking in knowledge of your entire surroundings all at once. Make a Constitution saving throw. You take {@damage 14d8} psychic damage on a failed save and half as much on a successful one. Regardless of the outcome of the roll, the amount of information you ram into your mind in a mere one minute takes a large toll on both your mind and body. You have disadvantage on all Intelligence checks and Intelligence saving throws for the next {@dice 1d4} days. A greater restoration or wish spell ends this effect.

You are now able to absorb the knowledge of every person, place, and what anyone is doing within 1 mile of you. Your mind is not actively thinking about every scenario at once. For example, within this 1 mile, you might now store somewhere in your mind the activities in a local tavern, but you won't be thinking of that until you specifically attempt to. When you try to retrieve knowledge about a specific location or person, you gain a mental photographic image of what you would see if you were a spectator to the situation. You retain the visual and auditory knowledge of everything that happened at that instance in time for the next 24 hours. For the duration of the spell, you can choose to use an action to switch to a different location.
A creature within the area that has a Wisdom score higher than your Wisdom score gets a sensation that they are being watched, though they do not know by whom or by what method.
For the duration of the spell, you are {@condition blinded} and {@condition deafened} to your own senses, and you are {@condition paralyzed}.

spell.name: Penetrate

m.text: a needle, ghast's eye, and opal worth at least 200 gp which the spell consumes

entries: The next time you make a ranged weapon attack before this spell ends, your projectile is infused with an entropic darkness that diffuses anything in its path. The range of your weapon attack changes into a 5-foot wide line area of effect up to the short range of your weapon. The projectile opens up a passage through any object or creature in the area, and you must make a separate ranged weapon attack roll for each creature caught in the line of penetration. If no creature in the area of effect is hit, the projectile loses its magic and it proceeds up to the long range with disadvantage as it normally would.

A creature hit with the magic-infused attack must make a Constitution saving throw, taking an additional {@damage 6d10} necrotic damage on a failed save and half as much on a successful one. Additionally, on a failed save, a creature that is not a construct or undead has its vital body parts rupture violently, as an object has passed through its body. Bleeding to death consciously, the creature now has to make death saving throws at the start of each of its turns, yet it retains the ability to perform anything it could normally do in a turn. The spell ends on the creature after three successful death saves and it instantly dies after three failures. Taking damage will not force the creature to fail a death saving throw like it would if it were {@condition unconscious}. A creature within 5 feet of an affected target can attempt to make a Wisdom ({@skill Medicine}) check as an action against your spell save DC, ending the spell effect on that creature on a success. The creature can attempt to make this check on itself as well, but it does so with disadvantage. The wound is visible to any creature that sees it, appearing as a black hole out on the front and back of where the target was hit. A greater restoration, heal, or wish spell will also end the effect on a target.

spell.name: Penumbrance

components.m: a shadow demon's claw

entries: A dark shadow rises from the ground, circling your body until it shrouds you completely. The shadow barrier you create protects you, and you are considered to be under half cover at all times until the spell ends. You also make Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks with advantage and can move 15 additional feet a turn while in either dim light or darkness. Additionally, until the spell ends, you can take the {@action Dash}, Disengage, or {@action Hide} action as a bonus action.

spell.name: Pin Missile

components.m: a golden pin

entries: A single golden dart of magical force shoots out to a creature within range. A creature targeted by this spell takes {@damage 6d4 + 6} force damage and needs to make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, the creature is {@condition stunned} until the end of its next turn.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 5th level or higher, the damage increases by {@dice 2d4} for each slot level above 4th.

spell.name: Plate of Stone

components.m: a bag of small pebbles

entries: You generate a shield made of multiple sheets of hard stone around a creature you touch. Until the spell ends, the target of this spell gains a temporary shield that has 10 hit points. Whenever the creature takes bludgeoning, piercing, or slashing damage from nonmagical attacks, the damage is redirected towards the shield. If an effect or attack brings the shield's hit points to 0, the spell ends, and any excess damage carries over to the creature.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, the shield gains 10 more hit points for every level above 1st.

spell.name: Power Leech

m.text: a leech and a black sapphire worth at least 200 gp, which the spell consumes

entries: You shoot a thin black beam of dark energy from the sapphire, stealing the strength away from a creature you see within range. The creature must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw or have its Strength score reduced by {@dice 1d6 + 1}. This reduction can only be reverted by a greater restoration, heal, or wish spell. Additionally, on a failed save, the creature takes {@damage 5d12 + 10} necrotic damage. A creature that has its Strength reduced to 0 dies.

You regain an amount of hit points equal to half of the necrotic damage you dealt, and your Strength score increases by the amount you reduced for the next hour. This increase does not allow your Strength to exceed 24.

spell.name: Power Word Bold
entries: A wave of strengthening energy washes over a creature you touch as you speak a word of power that activates all of its physical bodily defenses. The creature gains 30 temporary hit points and is resistant to all forms of bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage.

spell.name: Power Word Drain
entries: You speak a word of power that drains the mental and physical abilities of a creature. The target's muscles begin to fatigue, its legs begin to collapse, and it temporarily loses the ability to fight properly. If the creature you choose has 150 hit points or fewer, it immediately gains three points of {@condition exhaustion}. Otherwise, the spell has no effect. Additionally, you lose all points of {@condition exhaustion}, if any. For the duration the target still has any of its temporary {@condition exhaustion} points, any damage you deal to the target will recover your hit points for an amount equal to half the damage dealt.

These three points of {@condition exhaustion} are temporary and can be slowly removed. At the end of each of the creature's turns, it can make a Constitution saving throw, removing one of these temporary {@condition exhaustion} points on a success. A lesser restoration spell can remove one of these points, and a greater restoration spell removes all of the points.

spell.name: Power Word Mark
entries: You utter a word of power that exposes all the weaknesses in a creature's body. If the target has 150 hit points or fewer, it instantly becomes vulnerable to all damage. Otherwise, the spell has no effect. If the creature is reduced to 0 hit points as a result of the doubled damage from this spell, it regains 1 hit point.

The target must make a Constitution saving throw at the end of each of its turns. On a successful save, this effect of vulnerability ends. Dispel magic or any healing spell of 7th level or higher can also end this spell.

spell.name: Prayer of Glory

m.text: a shield and a large candle with the symbol of your deity engraved in it which the spell consumes

entries: Up to five creatures of your choice that have stayed in range during the entire casting time gains an amount of temporary hit points equal to {@dice 4d10} + your spellcasting modifier. Any creature affected becomes immune to being {@condition frightened} or {@condition charmed}, and can make all Charisma saving throws with advantage. You can also choose from one of the following effects to grant to all of the creatures if it matches your alignment. Any creature who has an alignment that does not match the effect does not get the benefit. These benefits last for 24 hours.

entries.name: Divine Blessing (Good)
entries: Any weapon attack deals an additional {@damage 1d10} radiant damage. You are immune to the {@condition blinded}, {@condition deafened}, {@condition paralyzed}, and {@condition poisoned} conditions. You gain resistance to poison damage.

entries.name: Infernal Blessing (Evil)
entries: Any weapon attack deals an additional {@damage 1d10} fire damage. A creature that makes a melee attack against an affected creature takes {@damage 2d10} fire damage.

entries.name: Order of Combat (Lawful)
entries: You can use your reaction to change one saving throw roll into a natural 10.

entries.name: Luck Bender (Chaotic)
entries: You can use your reaction to reroll one of your weapon attack rolls on your turn. You must use the new roll regardless of whether it is higher or lower than your original roll.

entries.name: Toughness (Any Neutral Alignment)
entries: Any damage dealt to you is reduced by 5. Additionally, the temporary hit points you get are replaced by an extended hit point maximum by the same amount, in which you heal that many hit points.

spell.name: Propelling Draft

components.m: a white bird's feather

entries: A powerful gale of unseen force shoots out from your hands affecting one Medium or smaller creature you see within range. The target must succeed on a Strength saving throw or take {@damage 1d8} bludgeoning damage and get pushed back 10 feet.
This spell's damage increases by {@dice 1d8} when you reach 5th level ({@dice 2d8}), 11th level ({@dice 3d8}), and 17th level ({@dice 4d8}).

spell.name: Prophecy

m.text: an object pertaining to your deity worth at least 1000 gp which the spell consumes, an iron cauldron filled with holy water if you are good or neutral or blood if you are evil, alchemist's supplies, and incense

entries: You reach out to a deity or god that you have faith in. Requesting a prophecy from a deity you do not truly invest in may give you an improper reading. As you perform alchemy and magic over the boiling cauldron, green smoke billows upwards until it forms a vague shape of your deity's face. You tell the deity the name of a creature that you know, as well as a description of a goal that they have. The deity will then tell you two facts about the results of the creature pursuing the goal: a key to success and a foreboding omen.

entries.name: Key to Success
entries: You receive knowledge about one thing that you must find, do, or accomplish in order for the goal to be guaranteed to be fulfilled.

entries.name: Foreboding Omen
entries: You receive knowledge about one result of what would happen if you fail to fulfill the prophecy properly.

For example, if you request a prophecy to know the readings about finding an archfey willing to grant you powers, your deity may tell you that you must locate an emerald with the name of the archfey inscribed in it as the key to success and may tell you that you might forever be trapped in the Feywild as the omen. In this case, if you do succeed in finding the emerald, it is guaranteed that you will meet this willing archfey. Divine beings are not necessarily omniscient, so if your deity does not know exactly how to respond without being misleading, or if a scenario is too easily changeable, they will reply with "unsure" and the spell ends. For example, asking your deity whether you will find true love one day may be met with "unsure" as a response.

The truth of a prophecy is undeniably accurate, but the closer you are to your god, the more detailed and rewarding the reading given is. The more unlikely a prophecy is to be fulfilled, or the more extreme a goal is, the harder it is to find the key to success and the easier it is to fall for the foreboding omen. Only one prophecy can apply to a single creature at a time. If you attempt to request for a second prophecy before the first one is fulfilled on the same creature, your spell slot will be consumed and nothing happens. Once either the prophecy is fulfilled or if the DM decides it is not possible for the key to be found (the emerald is disintegrated in the previous example), the spell ends, the creature is made aware, and a new prophecy can now be applied.

Casting this spell requires your deity to come up with a difficult answer as to not mislead you, and so you may or may not receive your prophecy immediately. If your deity responds immediately, the green smoke above the cauldron will display your prophecy to you visually, and maybe audibly. If not, then during the creature's next long rest, it will be visited by the god in its dreams, and it will receive it then. Attempting to cast prophecy again in the time before you or the creature receives an answer will force you to lose your spell slot without any effect.

spell.name: Protection from Magic
entries: For the duration, a willing creature you touch has advantage on saving throws against spells or other magical effects. Death saving throws and saving throws made to maintain concentration do not count as magical effects.

spell.name: Radiant Column
entries: A thin beam of shining opaque light strikes down at a point within range. A creature casting this spell that is not of a good alignment fails to connect to a deity willing to send down this mote of divine power, expending the spell slot and ending the spell. If you see the sky and it is clear, the column of light seemingly descends from a point infinitely high up. Any clouds obstructing the path automatically disperse to form a large 100-foot radius circular area where the beam can pass through. If underground or in a place where the sky is not present, the roof where you center the column opens a bright divine fissure allowing the column to strike down, seemingly having come from an extraplanar dimension. Bright light extends out from the column in all directions to 150 feet, and dim light shines out to 150 feet beyond that. The light is considered natural light, extends around corners, and remains for the duration of the spell.

Upon casting this spell, every creature in a 10-foot radius cylinder of infinite height centered around the point you choose must make a Constitution saving throw, taking {@damage 20d10} radiant damage on a failed save and half as much on a success. For the duration of the spell, any creature inside the column of light at the start of your turn or a creature that moves into its space, must repeat the saving throw and take the damage again. Until the spell ends, a creature within 20 feet of the center of the column is immune to all conditions that reduce the creature's speed to 0.

For every subsequent turn until the spell ends, you can use an action to cause the column to emit a burst of radiant light. Any creature within 40 feet of the center of the column must succeed on a Constitution saving throw or be {@condition blinded} until the end of its next turn and lose its concentration. Additionally, the creature takes {@damage 8d10} radiant damage on a failed save and half as much on a successful one. This 40-foot radius is also considered difficult terrain and the bright light rays that extend from the column makes the area lightly obscured.

If the spell lasts for the full duration, the divine light imprints a holy symbol into the ground where it is cast. As the column retracts upwards, a glowing runic symbol relating to the deity that facilitated the spell's casting appears in the burnt crater that the light created. Soft white sparks fly out of the symbol and it gives off a low hiss that resembles the sound of radiant fire. The symbol emits dim light out to 20 feet, and any creature not of a good alignment that enters the 10-foot area for the first time on their turn or starts its turn there takes 50 radiant damage. The symbol remains inscribed in the ground for 1 hour.

spell.name: Rary's Guiding Compass

components.m: a metal rod and a cherrywood leaf

entries: You place a subtle mental tracker on a creature you touch, attempting to create a directional link between you and the target. The target must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw or the spell takes effect. A willing target does not have to make this save and is marked.

Until the spell ends, your mental compass allows you to know the exact direction you must travel in to reach the target. If the creature enters another plane of existence, you know which plane it entered and the compass now points to the location it was last. A creature with {@sense truesight} or can see invisibility knows that a mark is placed on them to scry it's location, as an {@condition invisible} crown of rings lay above the target's head.

You can choose to cast this spell in a different way by using your action to infuse this spell into a projectile. Until the spell ends, you can attempt to place this tracker on any creature hit by the projectile. A creature that is hit must make a Wisdom saving throw, ending the spell on a success.
Every hour until the spell ends, the target can repeat the saving throw, ending the spell on a success.

spell.name: Ray of Disablement

components.m: a bone of a creature of size Large or bigger

entries: You release a solid red beam of energy at a creature you see within range. Make a ranged spell attack. On a hit, the creature takes {@dice 8d12} necrotic and must make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, the negative energy of the spell seeps into the muscles of the target, reducing its movement speed to half and causing one of the following effects of your choosing to happen.

items: The creature's arm boils with hot bubbles above the skin. Until the spell ends, the target takes {@damage 1d12} fire damage every single time it attacks with a melee weapon using that hand.
The creature's legs become extremely stiff and cannot use the {@action Dash} or {@action Disengage} action options in combat.
The creature's face becomes horribly disfigured and has disadvantage on all Charisma checks.
The creature becomes sluggish as the wave of energy washes over it, making Dexterity weapon attack rolls and checks with disadvantage.

entries: A creature can repeat the Constitution saving throw at the end of each of its turn, ending the movement speed reduction on a success or if 1 minute has passed since it was hit with the spell. The secondary negative effect lasts up to 24 hours, and can be removed with a greater restoration, heal, circlet of healing, or wish spell.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 6th level or higher, the damage increases by {@dice 1d12} for every level above 5th.

spell.name: Ray of Light
entries: A concentrated white beam of shining light radiates from your finger out to a creature you see within range. Make a ranged spell attack against the target. On a hit, the creature takes {@damage 8d6} radiant damage and shines with the same light from within its body. For up to 1 minute, the light stays centered on the creature, ending any effect on it that allows it to be {@condition invisible}, shedding bright light out to 30 feet and dim light for 30 feet beyond that.
At the end of each of the creature's turns, it can make a Constitution saving throw, ending the light effect on a success.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, the damage increases by {@dice 1d6} for every level above 3rd.

spell.name: Read Tome
entries: You gain the temporary ability to read through any text of any language at an incredibly fast rate. Until the spell ends, you can use an action to touch any book or tome and get a solid understanding of the material inside. When you do so, you can speak a small phrase, such as "Hill giant strength potion" or "Lost key of the Chuulic Ruins," and if the text contains any small portion of the phrase you say, you know the exact location of where that phrase is in the book. You know of all magic affecting the tome, and understand the nature and results of any magical effects.

Alternatively, you can spend the entire duration of the spell to focus all your mental energy on a single book or tome. By doing so, you absorb the information of the entire book, and can recall with ease any section or phrase inside the book. If the book is magical and it produces an effect as a result of reading it, the effects take place immediately when the spell ends. Reading a book and storing so much information in your mind in such a small frame of time is mentally debilitating, and you must succeed on an Intelligence saving throw or take {@damage 3d6} psychic damage.

spell.name: Restore Object
entries: Choose an object or a magical item of rarity rare or less. You can choose to remove any effect that has changed the properties of the item within the last 7 days. If it is a magical item, you can remove all magical effects off of the object, but you cannot remove curses.

spell.name: Rewind Time
entries: You wind back the hands of time, momentarily altering the continuous flow of the universe. Time reverts back 1 round so that in combat, you return to the end of your last turn. You carry all knowledge with you of what will happen, and you are able to issue out any commands that can be spoken in one round to inform others about what you saw. Initiative order continues forward from the creature after you normally.

During the casting of this spell, you have essentially generated yourself an extra pocket of forward time you can use to prepare an extra turn so that the moment you rewind time, you can perform an extra action and movement instantaneously. For example, you can move 30 feet forward and cast fireball before casting this spell. If you do so, once you revert back, other creatures will see you instantly teleport forward and an explosion out of thin air right after you finish your previous turn. The spell slot is consumed once you return.
On your next turn, all of your attacks have advantage and all attacks against you have disadvantage.

Doing so many things at once can be straining on your mind and body if the action you perform is too strenuous. Casting a spell 6th or higher in level as your extra action will give you one point of {@condition exhaustion}.

spell.name: Sharpening Smite
entries: The next time you hit a creature with a melee weapon attack that deals slashing or piercing damage before this spell ends, the blade of the weapon shines with a smooth white gleam, and the attack deals an additional {@damage 3d8} damage of that damage type. Additionally, you can land a critical on this hit if you roll a natural 18-20.

spell.name: Seethe
entries: You attempt to enrage a creature you see within range, bringing it into a frenzied state as its skin boils from anger. The target must make a Wisdom saving throw. A creature takes {@damage 8d8} psychic damage on a failed save and half as much on a success.

Additionally, on a failed save, the target enters a state of recklessness until the spell ends. While in this enraged state, all of the creature's melee attacks have advantage, but all attack rolls made against the creature are made with advantage. The intensity of the creature's anger also extends to its physical body. The target takes fire damage at the start of each of its turns as its skin heats up and boils. This damage starts at {@dice 1d8}, and increases by {@dice 1d8} every subsequent round to a maximum of {@dice 5d8}. A creature that touches the target or hits it with a melee attack while within 5 feet of it takes the same amount of fire damage, and all of its unarmed attacks also deal this additional fire damage. Creatures immune to being {@condition charmed} take only psychic damage from this spell and suffer no additional effects.

spell.name: Shock Bolt
entries: You launch a thin sphere of electrical energy out of your fingertips at a creature within range. Make a ranged spell attack. On a hit, the creature takes {@damage 4d6} lightning damage. Every creature within 20 feet of it must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw or be hit by the shocking bolt that jumps out from the original creature. A creature with the shocking bolt placed on them takes {@dice 4d6} at the end of its turn, and every creature within 20 feet of it must succeed on a Dexterity throw or the bolt will pass on to them, removing the bolt from itself. This way, if two creatures remain within 20 feet of each other for the duration of the spell, the creatures will pass the shock back and forth between each other, assuming both creatures constantly fail their saving throws. A creature can only have one shock placed on them at once, and the shock disappears from all creatures when the spell ends.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 6th level or higher, the damage increases by {@dice 1d6} for every level above 5th.

spell.name: Signal Flare

components.m: iron powder, charcoal, and a pinch of sawdust

entries: You create a tenuous pink flame inside a projectile of your choice. You can fire the projectile like normal, and until the spell ends, you can use a bonus action on any of your turns to instantly cause the projectile to burst open, spewing out violent violet sparks. The sparks generate dim light out to 30 feet, and it creates a loud crackling noise that can be heard from up to 100 feet away.

Alternatively, you can cause the projectile to burst in flames when you hit a creature as part of the action you used to shoot it. The flames bursting out of the arrow deals an additional {@damage 1d6} fire damage to the target if it hits.

spell.name: Sludge Mortar

components.m: A cup of the remains of a gelatinous cube

entries: You conjure a 15 foot cube of a translucent gelatinous mortar at a point centered within range. The conjuration is a construct, has an AC of 8, and has 100 hit points. The mortar is resistant to all piercing damage, but vulnerable to all bludgeoning damage. Any creature that successfully attacks the mortar with a melee weapon must make a Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check against your spell save DC. On a failed save, the weapon the creature used to attack the mortar becomes stuck, and it can only be pulled out with a successful Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check as an action on subsequent turns.

The space the gelatinous mortar occupies is considered difficult terrain. However, a creature that enters the space occupied by the mortar must make a Strength saving throw. On a failed save, the creature is subjected to the {@condition grappled} condition as it is now lodged inside. At the end of a creature turn that is lodged in the mortar, it takes {@damage 10d4} damage of a type corresponding to the color of the mortar. Another creature within 5 feet of the gelatinous mortar can attempt to pull out the stuck creature by making a successful Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check against your spell save DC.

As a bonus action on your turn, you can command the mortar to launch a pile of lethal gelatinous sludge in a direction of your choosing up to 30 feet away from the mortar. A sludge pile aimed towards the floor will take up a 10 feet by 10 feet space and will be considered difficult terrain. For every 5 feet a creature moves in the space of the lethal sludge pile, it takes {@damage 7d4} of damage corresponding to the color of the mortar. A creature that the sludge pile is aimed towards must make a Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, the creature is covered with sludge and takes {@damage 7d4} of damage corresponding to the color of the mortar. Additionally, the creature must make its subsequent melee attack rolls with disadvantage until it has taken an action to remove the sludge from its body. Launching a pile of sludge will cause the gelatinous mortar to take 10 damage as well as reduce the hitpoint maximum of the mortar by the same amount.
The color of the gelatinous mortar when conjured can be chosen by you from the options provided.

entries.name: Orange
entries: Inflicts Acid Damage

entries.name: Green
entries: Inflicts Poison Damage

entries.name: Purple
entries: Inflicts Necrotic Damage
Once the mortar loses all of its hit points or you have lost concentration on it, the structure melts into a pile of lethal gelatinous sludge on the space it occupied.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 6th level or higher, the damage dealt for all attacks increases by {@dice 2d4} for every level above 5th.

spell.name: Spark Trail
entries: The next time you make a ranged weapon attack on a creature within 90 feet of you before this spell ends, your projectile leaves a trail of small fiery sparks that rain on any creatures in the area of a 5-foot wide line between you and the creature. You deal an additional {@damage 1d6} fire damage on a creature you hit with your weapon, and any creature caught in the area of sparks takes 3 fire damage.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, the damage dealt by the sparks increases by 1 for every level above 1st.

spell.name: Spiritual Grace

components.m: a feather, birch leaves, and a brass rod

entries: You bestow upon yourself a divine elegance that can be inspired onto others. For the duration of the spell, you have advantage on any Dexterity or Charisma saving throws, as well as any ability check relating to these ability scores that you have proficiency in. Additionally, you can use a reaction on any of your turns until the spell ends to grant a creature within 30 feet of you advantage on a Dexterity or Charisma saving throw they are forced to make.

spell.name: Splintering Shot
entries: The next time you hit a creature with a ranged weapon attack before this spell ends, a scattershot of small metal arrows splinter out of the arrow tip. A creature hit by this arrow must make a Constitution saving throw, taking an additional {@damage 6d8} piercing damage on a failed save and half as much on a successful one.

Additionally, on a failed save, the splintering arrows pierce out behind the target, spraying forward in a 30-foot cone centered on the target and pointing away from the direction the arrow came from. Any creatures in the area of effect of this cone must make a Dexterity saving throw, taking {@dice 5d8} on a failed save and half as much on a successful one.

spell.name: Target
entries: A creature you choose must make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, you place a spectral red circle across its chest and back. The circle guides projectiles and weapons of any kind to strike true, even through thick armor. Until the spell ends, any spell or weapon attack against the creature has a +5 bonus on both the attack and damage roll.

spell.name: Tasha's Draining Tendrils

components.m: a long green vine from the Feywild

entries: You open up a rift in the ground connecting to the Feywild, releasing a large mass of wet and slimy green tendrils, flailing around in a 10-foot square within range. Any creature within the area of the spell when the tendrils appear must make a Dexterity saving throw, becoming {@condition grappled} and taking {@damage 3d4} bludgeoning damage on a failed save. On a successful one, the creature takes no damage and is not {@condition grappled}. The space of the tendrils is considered difficult terrain. A creature that is Huge or larger cannot be {@condition grappled}.

You can use your reaction when a creature ends its turn or enters an area within 5 feet from the tendrils to swing out and attempt to grapple it. The creature must make the same Dexterity saving throw to avoid being {@condition grappled} and take damage. At the end of a creature's turn, if it is {@condition grappled}, it takes {@damage 2d4} necrotic damage and its hit point maximum is decreased by the same amount of damage as the wrapping tendrils attempt to squirt the life out of it. Only three creatures can be {@condition grappled} at the same time. This health reduction is restored after a long rest or a greater restoration spell.
A creature can attempt to escape the grapple by using its action to make a Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check or a Dexterity ({@skill Acrobatics}) check against your spell save DC.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 3rd level or higher, the necrotic damage dealt by the tendrils increases by {@dice 1d4} for every level above 2nd level.

spell.name: Tenser's Acid Pool
entries: You transform the ground underneath a creature's feet into a bubbling pool of sticky white acid. A creature you see must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw or starts sinking into the pool. The creature takes {@damage 6d8} acid damage and is {@condition restrained}. At the end of every turn that the target is still inside of the pool, it automatically takes an additional {@damage 4d8} acid damage. The creature inside the pool can attempt to pull itself out of the pool by using an action to make a Strength saving throw, ending the spell on a success. Alternatively, a creature within 5 feet of it can use its action to make a Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check against your spell save DC to end the spell.

If the creature is still inside of the acid pool for the entirety of the spell's duration, the acid slowly disappears and restores itself to the original ground, trapping you in the earth. The pool is 5 feet deep, so if a creature that is shorter than 5 feet is trapped in the ground this way, it will begin suffocating.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 6th level or higher, the damage increases by {@dice 1d8} for both the initial and subsequent damage for every level above 5th.

spell.name: Terran Whisper
entries: You send a devastating ripple 30 feet forward and 5 feet wide in the floor, causing the ground to deform. Any creature who is on the line must make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, the creature takes {@damage 2d6} bludgeoning damage, and half as much on a success. The area is also considered difficult terrain.

Additionally, as a bonus action on any of your turns within 1 minute after the spell has been casted, you are able to split open the deformed ground slightly to release a strong blast of wind upwards. Any creature who is on the line must make a Dexterity saving throw, or take {@damage 1d6} bludgeoning damage and be knocked 10 feet away in a random direction. On a success, the creature takes half as much damage and is not knocked away. This ability can be used only once for each unopened line.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, the damage for the initial ripple increases by {@dice 1d6} for every level above 1st.

spell.name: Titanification
entries: You make a creature or object enormous and physically more powerful for the duration. Choose one willing creature within range. Until the spell ends, the creature will gain the following benefits.

items: The creature will swell in all dimensions, increasing its size by two classes. The resulting size cannot be anything less than Large. For example, a Medium creature would become Huge and a Large creature would become Gargantuan, but a Tiny creature would become Large.
The creature gains advantage on all Strength checks and saving throws.
The creature's Strength increases by 4, to a maximum of 24.
The creature gains resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage from all non magical weapons.
The creature's weapons swell in size as well, giving its attack an additional {@damage 1d8} damage bonus and allowing it to ignore all cover.
The creature's movement speed increases by 10 feet.
The creature's weapon reach increases by 5 feet.
All of the creature's attacks deal double damage to objects and structures.

spell.name: Tornado

components.m: a strand of a cloud giant's hair

entries: You create a large circular whirlwind with a radius of 20 feet at a point you can see in range. The tornado is a column of swirling air that is 150 feet tall. All creatures within the area of the tornado when conjured must make a Strength saving throw or take {@damage 2d6} bludgeoning damage and are sucked to the center of the tornado. While inside the tornado, a creature gains a flying speed equal to its speed, and the entire column is considered difficult terrain and heavily obscured. Creatures huge or gargantuan in size are not affected.

A creature within 60 feet of the center of the tornado has to make another Strength saving throw at the end of each of its turns or be pulled 15 feet closer to the center of the tornado. A creature that fails this saving throw and is inside the tornado also gets pulled up 10 feet. A creature or object that starts its turn inside of the tornado has to make a separate Strength saving throw, taking an amount of bludgeoning damage equal to {@damage 2d6} + a cumulative damage from objects in the tornado on a failed save, and half as much on a successful save. Objects get pulled in without the need for a Strength saving throw, and will take the initial {@damage 2d6} bludgeoning damage upon entering the tornado.
The cumulative damage is based on the type of creatures and objects within the tornado listed on the table below. The maximum damage the tornado can do in this way is {@dice 16d6}.

entries.name: Small
entries: {@dice 1d6}

entries.name: Medium
entries: {@dice 2d6}

entries.name: Large
entries: {@dice 4d6}

As an action on each of your subsequent turns, you can move the tornado up to 20 feet. Any creature inside the tornado will be carried along, and any creature that you enter the space of has to make the initial Strength saving throw or take {@damage 2d6} bludgeoning damage and is pulled to the center of the tornado.

spell.name: True Time Reversal

m.text: a pocket watch made of gold worth at least 1000 gp, which the spell consumes

entries: You attempt to break the foundations of time itself, performing the extraordinary feat of traveling back in time. You can revert universal time back up to 1 hour, carrying back with you all knowledge of what happened during that time. Everything that was to happen will happen as long as your decisions don't dramatically change an outcome. No pockets of time will be created, as anything that happened during the time leading up to this spell will be erased to be redone. To anybody but you, it would seem like you gained an uncanny foresight of what is to come in the next hour, and the only remaining trace of you casting this spell is your missing pocket watch.
Casting a spell requiring such a degree of arcana and mental fortitude can make the spell somewhat unpredictable. Roll a {@dice d20} when you cast this spell, and the results are shown below.
1. The spell fails, the spell slot and material component is consumed, and you take {@damage 10d6} psychic damage.
The spell turns back 10 minutes regardless of whatever you choose. Additionally, you take {@damage 4d6} psychic damage.
The spell happens as it normally would.
20. The spell happens normally and no material component is consumed.

spell.name: Undulation

components.m: a smooth stone and a blade of swampgrass

entries: You release a burst of rippling energy, transforming the ground into a calm waveform to push creatures away from you. All creatures touching the ground in a 40-foot cube area with you centered on a face must make a Strength saving throw. On a failed save, the creature is pushed back to the edge of the cube farthest away from you. On a successful save, the creature is not pushed back.

The ground continues magically undulating for 1 minute, rippling up and down in a slow manner. The area affected by the spell is considered difficult terrain for this duration, and creatures within the area must use its reaction every turn to balance itself on the wavy ground or fall {@condition prone}.

spell.name: Voltaic Smite
entries: The next time you hit a creature with a melee weapon attack before this spell ends, your weapon sparkles with crackling electrical energy, and the attack deals an additional {@damage 2d12} lightning damage. Additionally, the creature has to succeed on a Constitution saving throw or be {@condition paralyzed} until the end of its next turn.

spell.name: Vinefection

components.m: a vine at least 20 feet long

entries: A target within range must make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, you cause vines to grow uncontrollably in the creature's body. As the vines envelop the creature's organs and bones, it begins to feel weak, and their movement speed is reduced by 10 feet. On a successful save, the vines fail to take root in the body.

On the creature's next turn, it must make another Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, the vines rapidly intertwine themselves around each bone and tendon in the creature's body and begin to protrude out of their skin. The creature will feel even more {@condition restrained} as its movement speed is now reduced by 20 feet. Additionally, the creature gains vulnerability to fire damage if it is not already resistant or immune to fire damage. On a successful save, the vines dissipate within the creature's body. At this point, the creature can make Constitution saving throws at the end of each of their subsequent turns in order to resist the vines, ending the spell's effects.

spell.name: Wave of Weakness
entries: A 40-foot long misty wall formulates along the axis of your arms as you raise them like you are pulling earth out of the ground. You send forth a surge of weakening energy across the air, and any creature caught in the area of effect must make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, a creature suffers two points of {@condition exhaustion} and takes {@damage 6d6} necrotic damage. A successful save deals half as much damage and the creature does not get exhausted. Upon casting this spell, you need to succeed on a Constitution saving throw or suffer one point of {@condition exhaustion}.

spell.name: Weight

components.m: a sheet of lead

entries: You are able to manipulate and control the bodily mass of a creature or object you choose. A willing target's mass can increase up to three times as much as its original mass or decrease to a third of the original mass. The target feels no significant shifts in its own body but notices a change in the amount of pressure it creates on the surface it moves on. You can choose to make a piece of armor lighter with this spell, temporarily removing any disadvantage from Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks.

spell.name: Wildfire
entries: Until the spell ends, four separate Large spectral tiger heads appear in multiple unoccupied points you see within range, floating around in a form of brilliant scorching fire. Each tiger has 40 hit points and can only be hurt by cold or force damage. When it is reduced to 0 hit points, the tiger dissipates in a burst of flames. As a head appears, every creature within 20 feet of it must make a Dexterity saving throw, taking {@damage 3d6} fire damage on a failed save, and half as much on a successful one. The ground or any object that is within this area is set on fire and can begin spreading, even when the spell ends. As a bonus action on every turn until the spell ends, you can move one of the floating tigers up to 30 feet. Any creature within 20 feet of the tiger as it moves to the new location must make this Dexterity saving throw and the area there is now also caught on fire.

Any area that is set alight by the flames of the tiger stays on fire throughout the duration of the spell and even when the spell is over. Once the spell ends, the flames all become non-magical and instead natural, spreading at its own regular pace. Any creature that walks in any area set alight by the wildfire, starts its turn in the area, interacts with an object set on fire, or makes a melee attack against a tiger must make the same Dexterity saving throw. The wildfire can be put out by any method that would put a normal fire out.
A creature that willingly walks through a spectral tiger must make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, the creature takes {@dice 8d6}. On a success, the creature takes half as much.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 7th level or higher, the damage increases by {@dice 1d6} for every level above 6th.

spell.name: Withered Sward

components.m: a withered rose and purple dust

entries: You summon a 20-foot radius purplish black ring of dark energy within range. All natural plants in the area wither instantly as shadowy souls appear in the space, draining the life of anything in the radius. Any living creature in the area of effect has to make a Constitution saving throw, taking {@damage 6d12} necrotic damage on a failed save, and half as much on a successful one. A creature that fails its saving throw also has its Strength score reduced by {@dice 1d4}, and this reduction can only be reverted by a greater restoration, heal, or wish spell. A creature whose Strength is reduced to 0 instantly dies.

The circle stays for the duration of the spell, and it is considered difficult terrain. Any creature inside the circle makes death saving throws with disadvantage, and if it dies, the body turns into gray ash. A soul left in this way can only be returned by a wish or true resurrection spell.

spell.name: Whispering Blades

components.m: a small knife

entries: Three spectral swords appear around you, and they circle you in a 5-foot radius. Until the spell ends, the swords move with you, centered on you. Each hostile creature that starts its turn in the area of effect takes psychic damage equal to twice the amount of swords around you.

On each of your subsequent turns, you can use your bonus action to have a sword dart out to a creature you see within 30 feet of you. Make a ranged spell attack, and a creature that is hit takes {@damage 2d8} force damage.
The spell ends when you have used up your last sword.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, you summon an additional sword for every level above 3rd.
